021import static java.util.Objects.requireNonNull;

027import com.google.common.base.Strings;
028import com.google.common.util.concurrent.internal.InternalFutureFailureAccess;
029import com.google.common.util.concurrent.internal.InternalFutures;
030import com.google.errorprone.annotations.CanIgnoreReturnValue;
031import com.google.errorprone.annotations.ForOverride;
032import com.google.j2objc.annotations.J2ObjCIncompatible;
033import com.google.j2objc.annotations.ReflectionSupport;
034import com.google.j2objc.annotations.RetainedLocalRef;

055/**
056 * An abstract implementation of {@link ListenableFuture}, intended for advanced users only. More
057 * common ways to create a {@code ListenableFuture} include instantiating a {@link SettableFuture},
058 * submitting a task to a {@link ListeningExecutorService}, and deriving a {@code Future} from an
059 * existing one, typically using methods like {@link Futures#transform(ListenableFuture,
060 * com.google.common.base.Function, java.util.concurrent.Executor) Futures.transform} and {@link
061 * Futures#catching(ListenableFuture, Class, com.google.common.base.Function,
062 * java.util.concurrent.Executor) Futures.catching}.
063 *
064 * <p>This class implements all methods in {@code ListenableFuture}. Subclasses should provide a way
065 * to set the result of the computation through the protected methods {@link #set(Object)}, {@link
066 * #setFuture(ListenableFuture)} and {@link #setException(Throwable)}. Subclasses may also override
067 * {@link #afterDone()}, which will be invoked automatically when the future completes. Subclasses
068 * should rarely override other methods.
069 *
070 * @author Sven Mawson
071 * @author Luke Sandberg
072 * @since 1.0
073 */
074@SuppressWarnings({
075  // Whenever both tests are cheap and functional, it's faster to use &, | instead of &&, ||
076  "ShortCircuitBoolean",
077  "nullness", // TODO(b/147136275): Remove once our checker understands & and |.
078})
079@GwtCompatible(emulated = true)
080@ReflectionSupport(value = ReflectionSupport.Level.FULL)
081public abstract class AbstractFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> extends InternalFutureFailureAccess
082    implements ListenableFuture<V> {
083  static final boolean GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES;
084
085  static {
086    // System.getProperty may throw if the security policy does not permit access.
087    boolean generateCancellationCauses;
088    try {
089      generateCancellationCauses =
090          Boolean.parseBoolean(
091              System.getProperty("guava.concurrent.generate_cancellation_cause", "false"));
092    } catch (SecurityException e) {
093      generateCancellationCauses = false;
094    }
095    GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES = generateCancellationCauses;
096  }
097
098  /**
099   * Tag interface marking trusted subclasses. This enables some optimizations. The implementation
100   * of this interface must also be an AbstractFuture and must not override or expose for overriding
101   * any of the public methods of ListenableFuture.
102   */
103  interface Trusted<V extends @Nullable Object> extends ListenableFuture<V> {}
104
105  /**
106   * A less abstract subclass of AbstractFuture. This can be used to optimize setFuture by ensuring
107   * that {@link #get} calls exactly the implementation of {@link AbstractFuture#get}.
108   */
109  abstract static class TrustedFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> extends AbstractFuture<V>
110      implements Trusted<V> {
111    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
112    @Override
113    @ParametricNullness
114    public final V get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
115      return super.get();
116    }
117
118    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
119    @Override
120    @ParametricNullness
121    public final V get(long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
122        throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException, TimeoutException {
123      return super.get(timeout, unit);
124    }
125
126    @Override
127    public final boolean isDone() {
128      return super.isDone();
129    }
130
131    @Override
132    public final boolean isCancelled() {
133      return super.isCancelled();
134    }
135
136    @Override
137    public final void addListener(Runnable listener, Executor executor) {
138      super.addListener(listener, executor);
139    }
140
141    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
142    @Override
143    public final boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
144      return super.cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);
145    }
146  }
147
148  static final LazyLogger log = new LazyLogger(AbstractFuture.class);
149
150  // A heuristic for timed gets. If the remaining timeout is less than this, spin instead of
151  // blocking. This value is what AbstractQueuedSynchronizer uses.
152  private static final long SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS = 1000L;
153
154  private static final AtomicHelper ATOMIC_HELPER;
155
156  /**
157   * Returns the result of calling {@link MethodHandles#lookup} from inside {@link AbstractFuture}.
158   * By virtue of being created there, it has access to the private fields of {@link
159   * AbstractFuture}, so that access is available to anyone who calls this methodâ€”specifically, to
160   * {@link VarHandleAtomicHelper}.
161   *
162   * <p>This "shouldn't" be necessary: {@link VarHandleAtomicHelper} and {@link AbstractFuture}
163   * "should" be nestmates, so a call to {@link MethodHandles#lookup} inside {@link
164   * VarHandleAtomicHelper} "should" have access to each other's private fields. However, our
165   * open-source build uses {@code -source 8 -target 8}, so the class files from that build can't
166   * express nestmates. Thus, when those class files are used from Java 9 or higher (i.e., high
167   * enough to trigger the {@link VarHandle} code path), such a lookup would fail with an {@link
168   * IllegalAccessException}.
169   *
170   * <p>Note that we do not have a similar problem with the fields in {@link Waiter} because those
171   * fields are not private. (We could solve the problem with {@link AbstractFuture} fields in the
172   * same way if we wanted.)
173   */
174  private static MethodHandles.Lookup methodHandlesLookupFromWithinAbstractFuture() {
175    return MethodHandles.lookup();
176  }
177
178  static {
179    AtomicHelper helper;
180    Throwable thrownUnsafeFailure = null;
181    Throwable thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure = null;
182
183    helper = VarHandleAtomicHelperMaker.INSTANCE.tryMakeVarHandleAtomicHelper();
184    if (helper == null) {
185      try {
186        helper = new UnsafeAtomicHelper();
187      } catch (Exception | Error unsafeFailure) { // sneaky checked exception
188        thrownUnsafeFailure = unsafeFailure;
189        // catch absolutely everything and fall through to our
190        // 'AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper' The access control checks that ARFU does means
191        // the caller class has to be AbstractFuture instead of
192        // AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper, so we annoyingly define these here
193        try {
194          helper =
195              new AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper(
196                  newUpdater(Waiter.class, Thread.class, "thread"),
197                  newUpdater(Waiter.class, Waiter.class, "next"),
198                  newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Waiter.class, "waiters"),
199                  newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Listener.class, "listeners"),
200                  newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Object.class, "value"));
201        } catch (Exception // sneaky checked exception
202            | Error atomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure) {
203          // Some Android 5.0.x Samsung devices have bugs in JDK reflection APIs that cause
204          // getDeclaredField to throw a NoSuchFieldException when the field is definitely there.
205          // For these users fallback to a suboptimal implementation, based on synchronized. This
206          // will be a definite performance hit to those users.
207          thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure = atomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure;
208          helper = new SynchronizedHelper();
209        }
210      }
211    }
212    ATOMIC_HELPER = helper;
213
214    // Prevent rare disastrous classloading in first call to LockSupport.park.
215    // See: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8074773
216    @SuppressWarnings("unused")
217    Class<?> ensureLoaded = LockSupport.class;
218
219    // Log after all static init is finished; if an installed logger uses any Futures methods, it
220    // shouldn't break in cases where reflection is missing/broken.
221    if (thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure != null) {
222      log.get().log(Level.SEVERE, "UnsafeAtomicHelper is broken!", thrownUnsafeFailure);
223      log.get()
224          .log(
225              Level.SEVERE,
226              "AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper is broken!",
227              thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure);
228    }
229  }
230
231  private enum VarHandleAtomicHelperMaker {
232    INSTANCE {
233      /**
234       * Implementation used by non-J2ObjC environments (aside, of course, from those that have
235       * supersource for the entirety of {@link AbstractFuture}).
236       */
237      @Override
238      @J2ObjCIncompatible
239      @Nullable AtomicHelper tryMakeVarHandleAtomicHelper() {
240        try {
241          /*
242           * We first use reflection to check whether VarHandle exists. If we instead just tried to
243           * load our class directly (which would trigger non-reflective loading of VarHandle) from
244           * within a `try` block, then an error might be thrown even before we enter the `try`
245           * block: https://github.com/google/truth/issues/333#issuecomment-765652454
246           *
247           * Also, it's nice that this approach should let us catch *only* ClassNotFoundException
248           * instead of having to catch more broadly (potentially even including, say, a
249           * StackOverflowError).
250           */
251          Class.forName("java.lang.invoke.VarHandle");
252        } catch (ClassNotFoundException beforeJava9) {
253          return null;
254        }
255        return new VarHandleAtomicHelper();
256      }
257    };
258
259    /** Implementation used by J2ObjC environments, overridden for other environments. */
260    @Nullable AtomicHelper tryMakeVarHandleAtomicHelper() {
261      return null;
262    }
263  }
264
265  /** Waiter links form a Treiber stack, in the {@link #waiters} field. */
266  private static final class Waiter {
267    static final Waiter TOMBSTONE = new Waiter(false /* ignored param */);
268
269    volatile @Nullable Thread thread;
270    volatile @Nullable Waiter next;
271
272    /**
273     * Constructor for the TOMBSTONE, avoids use of ATOMIC_HELPER in case this class is loaded
274     * before the ATOMIC_HELPER. Apparently this is possible on some android platforms.
275     */
276    Waiter(boolean unused) {}
277
278    Waiter() {
279      // avoid volatile write, write is made visible by subsequent CAS on waiters field
280      ATOMIC_HELPER.putThread(this, Thread.currentThread());
281    }
282
283    // non-volatile write to the next field. Should be made visible by subsequent CAS on waiters
284    // field.
285    void setNext(@Nullable Waiter next) {
286      ATOMIC_HELPER.putNext(this, next);
287    }
288
289    void unpark() {
290      // This is racy with removeWaiter. The consequence of the race is that we may spuriously call
291      // unpark even though the thread has already removed itself from the list. But even if we did
292      // use a CAS, that race would still exist (it would just be ever so slightly smaller).
293      Thread w = thread;
294      if (w != null) {
295        thread = null;
296        LockSupport.unpark(w);
297      }
298    }
299  }
300
301  /**
302   * Marks the given node as 'deleted' (null waiter) and then scans the list to unlink all deleted
303   * nodes. This is an O(n) operation in the common case (and O(n^2) in the worst), but we are saved
304   * by two things.
305   *
306   * <ul>
307   *   <li>This is only called when a waiting thread times out or is interrupted. Both of which
308   *       should be rare.
309   *   <li>The waiters list should be very short.
310   * </ul>
311   */
312  private void removeWaiter(Waiter node) {
313    node.thread = null; // mark as 'deleted'
314    restart:
315    while (true) {
316      Waiter pred = null;
317      Waiter curr = waiters;
318      if (curr == Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
319        return; // give up if someone is calling complete
320      }
321      Waiter succ;
322      while (curr != null) {
323        succ = curr.next;
324        if (curr.thread != null) { // we aren't unlinking this node, update pred.
325          pred = curr;
326        } else if (pred != null) { // We are unlinking this node and it has a predecessor.
327          pred.next = succ;
328          if (pred.thread == null) { // We raced with another node that unlinked pred. Restart.
329            continue restart;
330          }
331        } else if (!ATOMIC_HELPER.casWaiters(this, curr, succ)) { // We are unlinking head
332          continue restart; // We raced with an add or complete
333        }
334        curr = succ;
335      }
336      break;
337    }
338  }
339
340  /** Listeners also form a stack through the {@link #listeners} field. */
341  private static final class Listener {
342    static final Listener TOMBSTONE = new Listener();
343    // null only for TOMBSTONE
344    final @Nullable Runnable task;
345    // null only for TOMBSTONE
346    final @Nullable Executor executor;
347
348    // writes to next are made visible by subsequent CAS's on the listeners field
349    @Nullable Listener next;
350
351    Listener(Runnable task, Executor executor) {
352      this.task = task;
353      this.executor = executor;
354    }
355
356    Listener() {
357      this.task = null;
358      this.executor = null;
359    }
360  }
361
362  /** A special value to represent {@code null}. */
363  private static final Object NULL = new Object();
364
365  /** A special value to represent failure, when {@link #setException} is called successfully. */
366  private static final class Failure {
367    static final Failure FALLBACK_INSTANCE =
368        new Failure(
369            new Throwable("Failure occurred while trying to finish a future.") {
370              @Override
371              public synchronized Throwable fillInStackTrace() {
372                return this; // no stack trace
373              }
374            });
375    final Throwable exception;
376
377    Failure(Throwable exception) {
378      this.exception = checkNotNull(exception);
379    }
380  }
381
382  /** A special value to represent cancellation and the 'wasInterrupted' bit. */
383  private static final class Cancellation {
384    // constants to use when GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES = false
385    static final @Nullable Cancellation CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED;
386    static final @Nullable Cancellation CAUSELESS_CANCELLED;
387
388    static {
389      if (GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES) {
390        CAUSELESS_CANCELLED = null;
391        CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED = null;
392      } else {
393        CAUSELESS_CANCELLED = new Cancellation(false, null);
394        CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED = new Cancellation(true, null);
395      }
396    }
397
398    final boolean wasInterrupted;
399    final @Nullable Throwable cause;
400
401    Cancellation(boolean wasInterrupted, @Nullable Throwable cause) {
402      this.wasInterrupted = wasInterrupted;
403      this.cause = cause;
404    }
405  }
406
407  /** A special value that encodes the 'setFuture' state. */
408  private static final class SetFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> implements Runnable {
409    final AbstractFuture<V> owner;
410    final ListenableFuture<? extends V> future;
411
412    SetFuture(AbstractFuture<V> owner, ListenableFuture<? extends V> future) {
413      this.owner = owner;
414      this.future = future;
415    }
416
417    @Override
418    public void run() {
419      if (owner.value != this) {
420        // nothing to do, we must have been cancelled, don't bother inspecting the future.
421        return;
422      }
423      Object valueToSet = getFutureValue(future);
424      if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(owner, this, valueToSet)) {
425        complete(
426            owner,
427            /*
428             * Interruption doesn't propagate through a SetFuture chain (see getFutureValue), so
429             * don't invoke interruptTask.
430             */
431            false);
432      }
433    }
434  }
435
436  // TODO(lukes): investigate using the @Contended annotation on these fields when jdk8 is
437  // available.
438  /**
439   * This field encodes the current state of the future.
440   *
441   * <p>The valid values are:
442   *
443   * <ul>
444   *   <li>{@code null} initial state, nothing has happened.
445   *   <li>{@link Cancellation} terminal state, {@code cancel} was called.
446   *   <li>{@link Failure} terminal state, {@code setException} was called.
447   *   <li>{@link SetFuture} intermediate state, {@code setFuture} was called.
448   *   <li>{@link #NULL} terminal state, {@code set(null)} was called.
449   *   <li>Any other non-null value, terminal state, {@code set} was called with a non-null
450   *       argument.
451   * </ul>
452   */
453  private volatile @Nullable Object value;
454
455  /** All listeners. */
456  private volatile @Nullable Listener listeners;
457
458  /** All waiting threads. */
459  private volatile @Nullable Waiter waiters;
460
461  /** Constructor for use by subclasses. */
462  protected AbstractFuture() {}
463
464  // Gets and Timed Gets
465  //
466  // * Be responsive to interruption
467  // * Don't create Waiter nodes if you aren't going to park, this helps reduce contention on the
468  //   waiters field.
469  // * Future completion is defined by when #value becomes non-null/non SetFuture
470  // * Future completion can be observed if the waiters field contains a TOMBSTONE
471
472  // Timed Get
473  // There are a few design constraints to consider
474  // * We want to be responsive to small timeouts, unpark() has non trivial latency overheads (I
475  //   have observed 12 micros on 64-bit linux systems to wake up a parked thread). So if the
476  //   timeout is small we shouldn't park(). This needs to be traded off with the cpu overhead of
477  //   spinning, so we use SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS which is what AbstractQueuedSynchronizer uses for
478  //   similar purposes.
479  // * We want to behave reasonably for timeouts of 0
480  // * We are more responsive to completion than timeouts. This is because parkNanos depends on
481  //   system scheduling and as such we could either miss our deadline, or unpark() could be delayed
482  //   so that it looks like we timed out even though we didn't. For comparison FutureTask respects
483  //   completion preferably and AQS is non-deterministic (depends on where in the queue the waiter
484  //   is). If we wanted to be strict about it, we could store the unpark() time in the Waiter node
485  //   and we could use that to make a decision about whether or not we timed out prior to being
486  //   unparked.
487
488  /**
489   * {@inheritDoc}
490   *
491   * <p>The default {@link AbstractFuture} implementation throws {@code InterruptedException} if the
492   * current thread is interrupted during the call, even if the value is already available.
493   *
494   * @throws CancellationException {@inheritDoc}
495   */
496  @SuppressWarnings("LabelledBreakTarget") // TODO(b/345814817): Maybe fix?
497  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
498  @Override
499  @ParametricNullness
500  public V get(long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
501      throws InterruptedException, TimeoutException, ExecutionException {
502    // NOTE: if timeout < 0, remainingNanos will be < 0 and we will fall into the while(true) loop
503    // at the bottom and throw a timeoutexception.
504    final long timeoutNanos = unit.toNanos(timeout); // we rely on the implicit null check on unit.
505    long remainingNanos = timeoutNanos;
506    if (Thread.interrupted()) {
507      throw new InterruptedException();
508    }
509    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
510    if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
511      return getDoneValue(localValue);
512    }
513    // we delay calling nanoTime until we know we will need to either park or spin
514    final long endNanos = remainingNanos > 0 ? System.nanoTime() + remainingNanos : 0;
515    long_wait_loop:
516    if (remainingNanos >= SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS) {
517      Waiter oldHead = waiters;
518      if (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
519        Waiter node = new Waiter();
520        do {
521          node.setNext(oldHead);
522          if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casWaiters(this, oldHead, node)) {
523            while (true) {
524              OverflowAvoidingLockSupport.parkNanos(this, remainingNanos);
525              // Check interruption first, if we woke up due to interruption we need to honor that.
526              if (Thread.interrupted()) {
527                removeWaiter(node);
528                throw new InterruptedException();
529              }
530
531              // Otherwise re-read and check doneness. If we loop then it must have been a spurious
532              // wakeup
533              localValue = value;
534              if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
535                return getDoneValue(localValue);
536              }
537
538              // timed out?
539              remainingNanos = endNanos - System.nanoTime();
540              if (remainingNanos < SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS) {
541                // Remove the waiter, one way or another we are done parking this thread.
542                removeWaiter(node);
543                break long_wait_loop; // jump down to the busy wait loop
544              }
545            }
546          }
547          oldHead = waiters; // re-read and loop.
548        } while (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
549      }
550      // re-read value, if we get here then we must have observed a TOMBSTONE while trying to add a
551      // waiter.
552      // requireNonNull is safe because value is always set before TOMBSTONE.
553      return getDoneValue(requireNonNull(value));
554    }
555    // If we get here then we have remainingNanos < SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS and there is no node on the
556    // waiters list
557    while (remainingNanos > 0) {
558      localValue = value;
559      if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
560        return getDoneValue(localValue);
561      }
562      if (Thread.interrupted()) {
563        throw new InterruptedException();
564      }
565      remainingNanos = endNanos - System.nanoTime();
566    }
567
568    String futureToString = toString();
569    final String unitString = unit.toString().toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT);
570    String message = "Waited " + timeout + " " + unit.toString().toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT);
571    // Only report scheduling delay if larger than our spin threshold - otherwise it's just noise
572    if (remainingNanos + SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS < 0) {
573      // We over-waited for our timeout.
574      message += " (plus ";
575      long overWaitNanos = -remainingNanos;
576      long overWaitUnits = unit.convert(overWaitNanos, NANOSECONDS);
577      long overWaitLeftoverNanos = overWaitNanos - unit.toNanos(overWaitUnits);
578      boolean shouldShowExtraNanos =
579          overWaitUnits == 0 || overWaitLeftoverNanos > SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS;
580      if (overWaitUnits > 0) {
581        message += overWaitUnits + " " + unitString;
582        if (shouldShowExtraNanos) {
583          message += ",";
584        }
585        message += " ";
586      }
587      if (shouldShowExtraNanos) {
588        message += overWaitLeftoverNanos + " nanoseconds ";
589      }
590
591      message += "delay)";
592    }
593    // It's confusing to see a completed future in a timeout message; if isDone() returns false,
594    // then we know it must have given a pending toString value earlier. If not, then the future
595    // completed after the timeout expired, and the message might be success.
596    if (isDone()) {
597      throw new TimeoutException(message + " but future completed as timeout expired");
598    }
599    throw new TimeoutException(message + " for " + futureToString);
600  }
601
602  /**
603   * {@inheritDoc}
604   *
605   * <p>The default {@link AbstractFuture} implementation throws {@code InterruptedException} if the
606   * current thread is interrupted during the call, even if the value is already available.
607   *
608   * @throws CancellationException {@inheritDoc}
609   */
610  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
611  @Override
612  @ParametricNullness
613  public V get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
614    if (Thread.interrupted()) {
615      throw new InterruptedException();
616    }
617    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
618    if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
619      return getDoneValue(localValue);
620    }
621    Waiter oldHead = waiters;
622    if (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
623      Waiter node = new Waiter();
624      do {
625        node.setNext(oldHead);
626        if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casWaiters(this, oldHead, node)) {
627          // we are on the stack, now wait for completion.
628          while (true) {
629            LockSupport.park(this);
630            // Check interruption first, if we woke up due to interruption we need to honor that.
631            if (Thread.interrupted()) {
632              removeWaiter(node);
633              throw new InterruptedException();
634            }
635            // Otherwise re-read and check doneness. If we loop then it must have been a spurious
636            // wakeup
637            localValue = value;
638            if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
639              return getDoneValue(localValue);
640            }
641          }
642        }
643        oldHead = waiters; // re-read and loop.
644      } while (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
645    }
646    // re-read value, if we get here then we must have observed a TOMBSTONE while trying to add a
647    // waiter.
648    // requireNonNull is safe because value is always set before TOMBSTONE.
649    return getDoneValue(requireNonNull(value));
650  }
651
652  /** Unboxes {@code obj}. Assumes that obj is not {@code null} or a {@link SetFuture}. */
653  @ParametricNullness
654  private V getDoneValue(Object obj) throws ExecutionException {
655    // While this seems like it might be too branch-y, simple benchmarking proves it to be
656    // unmeasurable (comparing done AbstractFutures with immediateFuture)
657    if (obj instanceof Cancellation) {
658      Cancellation cancellation = (Cancellation) obj;
659      Throwable cause = cancellation.cause;
660      throw cancellationExceptionWithCause("Task was cancelled.", cause);
661    } else if (obj instanceof Failure) {
662      Failure failure = (Failure) obj;
663      Throwable exception = failure.exception;
664      throw new ExecutionException(exception);
665    } else if (obj == NULL) {
666      /*
667       * It's safe to return null because we would only have stored it in the first place if it were
668       * a valid value for V.
669       */
670      return uncheckedNull();
671    } else {
672      @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // this is the only other option
673      V asV = (V) obj;
674      return asV;
675    }
676  }
677
678  @Override
679  public boolean isDone() {
680    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
681    return localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof SetFuture);
682  }
683
684  @Override
685  public boolean isCancelled() {
686    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
687    return localValue instanceof Cancellation;
688  }
689
690  /**
691   * {@inheritDoc}
692   *
693   * <p>If a cancellation attempt succeeds on a {@code Future} that had previously been {@linkplain
694   * #setFuture set asynchronously}, then the cancellation will also be propagated to the delegate
695   * {@code Future} that was supplied in the {@code setFuture} call.
696   *
697   * <p>Rather than override this method to perform additional cancellation work or cleanup,
698   * subclasses should override {@link #afterDone}, consulting {@link #isCancelled} and {@link
699   * #wasInterrupted} as necessary. This ensures that the work is done even if the future is
700   * cancelled without a call to {@code cancel}, such as by calling {@code
701   * setFuture(cancelledFuture)}.
702   *
703   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
704   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
705   */
706  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
707  @Override
708  public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
709    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
710    boolean rValue = false;
711    if (localValue == null | localValue instanceof SetFuture) {
712      // Try to delay allocating the exception. At this point we may still lose the CAS, but it is
713      // certainly less likely.
714      Object valueToSet =
715          GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES
716              ? new Cancellation(
717                  mayInterruptIfRunning, new CancellationException("Future.cancel() was called."))
718              /*
719               * requireNonNull is safe because we've initialized these if
720               * !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
721               *
722               * TODO(cpovirk): Maybe it would be cleaner to define a CancellationSupplier interface
723               * with two implementations, one that contains causeless Cancellation instances and
724               * the other of which creates new Cancellation instances each time it's called? Yet
725               * another alternative is to fill in a non-null value for each of the fields no matter
726               * what and to just not use it if !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
727               */
728              : requireNonNull(
729                  mayInterruptIfRunning
730                      ? Cancellation.CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED
731                      : Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED);
732      AbstractFuture<?> abstractFuture = this;
733      while (true) {
734        if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(abstractFuture, localValue, valueToSet)) {
735          rValue = true;
736          complete(abstractFuture, mayInterruptIfRunning);
737          if (localValue instanceof SetFuture) {
738            // propagate cancellation to the future set in setfuture, this is racy, and we don't
739            // care if we are successful or not.
740            ListenableFuture<?> futureToPropagateTo = ((SetFuture) localValue).future;
741            if (futureToPropagateTo instanceof Trusted) {
742              // If the future is a TrustedFuture then we specifically avoid calling cancel()
743              // this has 2 benefits
744              // 1. for long chains of futures strung together with setFuture we consume less stack
745              // 2. we avoid allocating Cancellation objects at every level of the cancellation
746              //    chain
747              // We can only do this for TrustedFuture, because TrustedFuture.cancel is final and
748              // does nothing but delegate to this method.
749              AbstractFuture<?> trusted = (AbstractFuture<?>) futureToPropagateTo;
750              localValue = trusted.value;
751              if (localValue == null | localValue instanceof SetFuture) {
752                abstractFuture = trusted;
753                continue; // loop back up and try to complete the new future
754              }
755            } else {
756              // not a TrustedFuture, call cancel directly.
757              futureToPropagateTo.cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);
758            }
759          }
760          break;
761        }
762        // obj changed, reread
763        localValue = abstractFuture.value;
764        if (!(localValue instanceof SetFuture)) {
765          // obj cannot be null at this point, because value can only change from null to non-null.
766          // So if value changed (and it did since we lost the CAS), then it cannot be null and
767          // since it isn't a SetFuture, then the future must be done and we should exit the loop
768          break;
769        }
770      }
771    }
772    return rValue;
773  }
774
775  /**
776   * Subclasses can override this method to implement interruption of the future's computation. The
777   * method is invoked automatically by a successful call to {@link #cancel(boolean) cancel(true)}.
778   *
779   * <p>The default implementation does nothing.
780   *
781   * <p>This method is likely to be deprecated. Prefer to override {@link #afterDone}, checking
782   * {@link #wasInterrupted} to decide whether to interrupt your task.
783   *
784   * @since 10.0
785   */
786  protected void interruptTask() {}
787
788  /**
789   * Returns true if this future was cancelled with {@code mayInterruptIfRunning} set to {@code
790   * true}.
791   *
792   * @since 14.0
793   */
794  protected final boolean wasInterrupted() {
795    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
796    return (localValue instanceof Cancellation) && ((Cancellation) localValue).wasInterrupted;
797  }
798
799  /**
800   * {@inheritDoc}
801   *
802   * @since 10.0
803   */
804  @Override
805  public void addListener(Runnable listener, Executor executor) {
806    checkNotNull(listener, "Runnable was null.");
807    checkNotNull(executor, "Executor was null.");
808    // Checking isDone and listeners != TOMBSTONE may seem redundant, but our contract for
809    // addListener says that listeners execute 'immediate' if the future isDone(). However, our
810    // protocol for completing a future is to assign the value field (which sets isDone to true) and
811    // then to release waiters, followed by executing afterDone(), followed by releasing listeners.
812    // That means that it is possible to observe that the future isDone and that your listeners
813    // don't execute 'immediately'.  By checking isDone here we avoid that.
814    // A corollary to all that is that we don't need to check isDone inside the loop because if we
815    // get into the loop we know that we weren't done when we entered and therefore we aren't under
816    // an obligation to execute 'immediately'.
817    if (!isDone()) {
818      Listener oldHead = listeners;
819      if (oldHead != Listener.TOMBSTONE) {
820        Listener newNode = new Listener(listener, executor);
821        do {
822          newNode.next = oldHead;
823          if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casListeners(this, oldHead, newNode)) {
824            return;
825          }
826          oldHead = listeners; // re-read
827        } while (oldHead != Listener.TOMBSTONE);
828      }
829    }
830    // If we get here then the Listener TOMBSTONE was set, which means the future is done, call
831    // the listener.
832    executeListener(listener, executor);
833  }
834
835  /**
836   * Sets the result of this {@code Future} unless this {@code Future} has already been cancelled or
837   * set (including {@linkplain #setFuture set asynchronously}). When a call to this method returns,
838   * the {@code Future} is guaranteed to be {@linkplain #isDone done} <b>only if</b> the call was
839   * accepted (in which case it returns {@code true}). If it returns {@code false}, the {@code
840   * Future} may have previously been set asynchronously, in which case its result may not be known
841   * yet. That result, though not yet known, cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*}
842   * method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
843   *
844   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
845   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
846   *
847   * @param value the value to be used as the result
848   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, completing the {@code Future}
849   */
850  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
851  protected boolean set(@ParametricNullness V value) {
852    Object valueToSet = value == null ? NULL : value;
853    if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
854      complete(this, /*callInterruptTask=*/ false);
855      return true;
856    }
857    return false;
858  }
859
860  /**
861   * Sets the failed result of this {@code Future} unless this {@code Future} has already been
862   * cancelled or set (including {@linkplain #setFuture set asynchronously}). When a call to this
863   * method returns, the {@code Future} is guaranteed to be {@linkplain #isDone done} <b>only if</b>
864   * the call was accepted (in which case it returns {@code true}). If it returns {@code false}, the
865   * {@code Future} may have previously been set asynchronously, in which case its result may not be
866   * known yet. That result, though not yet known, cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*}
867   * method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
868   *
869   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
870   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
871   *
872   * @param throwable the exception to be used as the failed result
873   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, completing the {@code Future}
874   */
875  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
876  protected boolean setException(Throwable throwable) {
877    Object valueToSet = new Failure(checkNotNull(throwable));
878    if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
879      complete(this, /*callInterruptTask=*/ false);
880      return true;
881    }
882    return false;
883  }
884
885  /**
886   * Sets the result of this {@code Future} to match the supplied input {@code Future} once the
887   * supplied {@code Future} is done, unless this {@code Future} has already been cancelled or set
888   * (including "set asynchronously," defined below).
889   *
890   * <p>If the supplied future is {@linkplain #isDone done} when this method is called and the call
891   * is accepted, then this future is guaranteed to have been completed with the supplied future by
892   * the time this method returns. If the supplied future is not done and the call is accepted, then
893   * the future will be <i>set asynchronously</i>. Note that such a result, though not yet known,
894   * cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*} method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
895   *
896   * <p>If the call {@code setFuture(delegate)} is accepted and this {@code Future} is later
897   * cancelled, cancellation will be propagated to {@code delegate}. Additionally, any call to
898   * {@code setFuture} after any cancellation will propagate cancellation to the supplied {@code
899   * Future}.
900   *
901   * <p>Note that, even if the supplied future is cancelled and it causes this future to complete,
902   * it will never trigger interruption behavior. In particular, it will not cause this future to
903   * invoke the {@link #interruptTask} method, and the {@link #wasInterrupted} method will not
904   * return {@code true}.
905   *
906   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
907   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
908   *
909   * @param future the future to delegate to
910   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, indicating that the {@code Future} was not previously
911   *     cancelled or set.
912   * @since 19.0
913   */
914  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
915  @SuppressWarnings("Interruption") // We are propagating an interrupt from a caller.
916  protected boolean setFuture(ListenableFuture<? extends V> future) {
917    checkNotNull(future);
918    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
919    if (localValue == null) {
920      if (future.isDone()) {
921        Object value = getFutureValue(future);
922        if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(this, null, value)) {
923          complete(
924              this,
925              /*
926               * Interruption doesn't propagate through a SetFuture chain (see getFutureValue), so
927               * don't invoke interruptTask.
928               */
929              false);
930          return true;
931        }
932        return false;
933      }
934      SetFuture<V> valueToSet = new SetFuture<>(this, future);
935      if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
936        // the listener is responsible for calling completeWithFuture, directExecutor is appropriate
937        // since all we are doing is unpacking a completed future which should be fast.
938        try {
939          future.addListener(valueToSet, DirectExecutor.INSTANCE);
940        } catch (Throwable t) {
941          // Any Exception is either a RuntimeException or sneaky checked exception.
942          //
943          // addListener has thrown an exception! SetFuture.run can't throw any exceptions so this
944          // must have been caused by addListener itself. The most likely explanation is a
945          // misconfigured mock. Try to switch to Failure.
946          Failure failure;
947          try {
948            failure = new Failure(t);
949          } catch (Exception | Error oomMostLikely) { // sneaky checked exception
950            failure = Failure.FALLBACK_INSTANCE;
951          }
952          // Note: The only way this CAS could fail is if cancel() has raced with us. That is ok.
953          boolean unused = ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(this, valueToSet, failure);
954        }
955        return true;
956      }
957      localValue = value; // we lost the cas, fall through and maybe cancel
958    }
959    // The future has already been set to something. If it is cancellation we should cancel the
960    // incoming future.
961    if (localValue instanceof Cancellation) {
962      // we don't care if it fails, this is best-effort.
963      future.cancel(((Cancellation) localValue).wasInterrupted);
964    }
965    return false;
966  }
967
968  /**
969   * Returns a value that satisfies the contract of the {@link #value} field based on the state of
970   * given future.
971   *
972   * <p>This is approximately the inverse of {@link #getDoneValue(Object)}
973   */
974  private static Object getFutureValue(ListenableFuture<?> future) {
975    if (future instanceof Trusted) {
976      // Break encapsulation for TrustedFuture instances since we know that subclasses cannot
977      // override .get() (since it is final) and therefore this is equivalent to calling .get()
978      // and unpacking the exceptions like we do below (just much faster because it is a single
979      // field read instead of a read, several branches and possibly creating exceptions).
980      Object v = ((AbstractFuture<?>) future).value;
981      if (v instanceof Cancellation) {
982        // If the other future was interrupted, clear the interrupted bit while preserving the cause
983        // this will make it consistent with how non-trustedfutures work which cannot propagate the
984        // wasInterrupted bit
985        Cancellation c = (Cancellation) v;
986        if (c.wasInterrupted) {
987          v =
988              c.cause != null
989                  ? new Cancellation(/* wasInterrupted= */ false, c.cause)
990                  : Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED;
991        }
992      }
993      // requireNonNull is safe as long as we call this method only on completed futures.
994      return requireNonNull(v);
995    }
996    if (future instanceof InternalFutureFailureAccess) {
997      Throwable throwable =
998          InternalFutures.tryInternalFastPathGetFailure((InternalFutureFailureAccess) future);
999      if (throwable != null) {
1000        return new Failure(throwable);
1001      }
1002    }
1003    boolean wasCancelled = future.isCancelled();
1004    // Don't allocate a CancellationException if it's not necessary
1005    if (!GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES & wasCancelled) {
1006      /*
1007       * requireNonNull is safe because we've initialized CAUSELESS_CANCELLED if
1008       * !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
1009       */
1010      return requireNonNull(Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED);
1011    }
1012    // Otherwise calculate the value by calling .get()
1013    try {
1014      Object v = getUninterruptibly(future);
1015      if (wasCancelled) {
1016        return new Cancellation(
1017            false,
1018            new IllegalArgumentException(
1019                "get() did not throw CancellationException, despite reporting "
1020                    + "isCancelled() == true: "
1021                    + future));
1022      }
1023      return v == null ? NULL : v;
1024    } catch (ExecutionException exception) {
1025      if (wasCancelled) {
1026        return new Cancellation(
1027            false,
1028            new IllegalArgumentException(
1029                "get() did not throw CancellationException, despite reporting "
1030                    + "isCancelled() == true: "
1031                    + future,
1032                exception));
1033      }
1034      return new Failure(exception.getCause());
1035    } catch (CancellationException cancellation) {
1036      if (!wasCancelled) {
1037        return new Failure(
1038            new IllegalArgumentException(
1039                "get() threw CancellationException, despite reporting isCancelled() == false: "
1040                    + future,
1041                cancellation));
1042      }
1043      return new Cancellation(false, cancellation);
1044    } catch (Exception | Error t) { // sneaky checked exception
1045      return new Failure(t);
1046    }
1047  }
1048
1049  /**
1050   * An inlined private copy of {@link Uninterruptibles#getUninterruptibly} used to break an
1051   * internal dependency on other /util/concurrent classes.
1052   */
1053  @ParametricNullness
1054  private static <V extends @Nullable Object> V getUninterruptibly(Future<V> future)
1055      throws ExecutionException {
1056    boolean interrupted = false;
1057    try {
1058      while (true) {
1059        try {
1060          return future.get();
1061        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
1062          interrupted = true;
1063        }
1064      }
1065    } finally {
1066      if (interrupted) {
1067        Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
1068      }
1069    }
1070  }
1071
1072  /** Unblocks all threads and runs all listeners. */
1073  private static void complete(AbstractFuture<?> param, boolean callInterruptTask) {
1074    // Declare a "true" local variable so that the Checker Framework will infer nullness.
1075    AbstractFuture<?> future = param;
1076
1077    Listener next = null;
1078    outer:
1079    while (true) {
1080      future.releaseWaiters();
1081      /*
1082       * We call interruptTask() immediately before afterDone() so that migrating between the two
1083       * can be a no-op.
1084       */
1085      if (callInterruptTask) {
1086        future.interruptTask();
1087        /*
1088         * Interruption doesn't propagate through a SetFuture chain (see getFutureValue), so don't
1089         * invoke interruptTask on any subsequent futures.
1090         */
1091        callInterruptTask = false;
1092      }
1093      // We call this before the listeners in order to avoid needing to manage a separate stack data
1094      // structure for them.  Also, some implementations rely on this running prior to listeners
1095      // so that the cleanup work is visible to listeners.
1096      // afterDone() should be generally fast and only used for cleanup work... but in theory can
1097      // also be recursive and create StackOverflowErrors
1098      future.afterDone();
1099      // push the current set of listeners onto next
1100      next = future.clearListeners(next);
1101      future = null;
1102      while (next != null) {
1103        Listener curr = next;
1104        next = next.next;
1105        /*
1106         * requireNonNull is safe because the listener stack never contains TOMBSTONE until after
1107         * clearListeners.
1108         */
1109        Runnable task = requireNonNull(curr.task);
1110        if (task instanceof SetFuture) {
1111          SetFuture<?> setFuture = (SetFuture<?>) task;
1112          // We unwind setFuture specifically to avoid StackOverflowErrors in the case of long
1113          // chains of SetFutures
1114          // Handling this special case is important because there is no way to pass an executor to
1115          // setFuture, so a user couldn't break the chain by doing this themselves.  It is also
1116          // potentially common if someone writes a recursive Futures.transformAsync transformer.
1117          future = setFuture.owner;
1118          if (future.value == setFuture) {
1119            Object valueToSet = getFutureValue(setFuture.future);
1120            if (ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(future, setFuture, valueToSet)) {
1121              continue outer;
1122            }
1123          }
1124          // otherwise the future we were trying to set is already done.
1125        } else {
1126          /*
1127           * requireNonNull is safe because the listener stack never contains TOMBSTONE until after
1128           * clearListeners.
1129           */
1130          executeListener(task, requireNonNull(curr.executor));
1131        }
1132      }
1133      break;
1134    }
1135  }
1136
1137  /**
1138   * Callback method that is called exactly once after the future is completed.
1139   *
1140   * <p>If {@link #interruptTask} is also run during completion, {@link #afterDone} runs after it.
1141   *
1142   * <p>The default implementation of this method in {@code AbstractFuture} does nothing. This is
1143   * intended for very lightweight cleanup work, for example, timing statistics or clearing fields.
1144   * If your task does anything heavier consider, just using a listener with an executor.
1145   *
1146   * @since 20.0
1147   */
1148  @ForOverride
1149  protected void afterDone() {}
1150
1151  // TODO(b/114236866): Inherit doc from InternalFutureFailureAccess. Also, -link to its URL.
1152  /**
1153   * Usually returns {@code null} but, if this {@code Future} has failed, may <i>optionally</i>
1154   * return the cause of the failure. "Failure" means specifically "completed with an exception"; it
1155   * does not include "was cancelled." To be explicit: If this method returns a non-null value,
1156   * then:
1157   *
1158   * <ul>
1159   *   <li>{@code isDone()} must return {@code true}
1160   *   <li>{@code isCancelled()} must return {@code false}
1161   *   <li>{@code get()} must not block, and it must throw an {@code ExecutionException} with the
1162   *       return value of this method as its cause
1163   * </ul>
1164   *
1165   * <p>This method is {@code protected} so that classes like {@code
1166   * com.google.common.util.concurrent.SettableFuture} do not expose it to their users as an
1167   * instance method. In the unlikely event that you need to call this method, call {@link
1168   * InternalFutures#tryInternalFastPathGetFailure(InternalFutureFailureAccess)}.
1169   *
1170   * @since 27.0
1171   */
1172  @Override
1173  /*
1174   * We should annotate the superclass, InternalFutureFailureAccess, to say that its copy of this
1175   * method returns @Nullable, too. However, we're not sure if we want to make any changes to that
1176   * class, since it's in a separate artifact that we planned to release only a single version of.
1177   */
1178  protected final @Nullable Throwable tryInternalFastPathGetFailure() {
1179    if (this instanceof Trusted) {
1180      @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
1181      if (localValue instanceof Failure) {
1182        return ((Failure) localValue).exception;
1183      }
1184    }
1185    return null;
1186  }
1187
1188  /**
1189   * If this future has been cancelled (and possibly interrupted), cancels (and possibly interrupts)
1190   * the given future (if available).
1191   */
1192  final void maybePropagateCancellationTo(@Nullable Future<?> related) {
1193    if (related != null & isCancelled()) {
1194      related.cancel(wasInterrupted());
1195    }
1196  }
1197
1198  /** Releases all threads in the {@link #waiters} list, and clears the list. */
1199  private void releaseWaiters() {
1200    Waiter head = ATOMIC_HELPER.gasWaiters(this, Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
1201    for (Waiter currentWaiter = head; currentWaiter != null; currentWaiter = currentWaiter.next) {
1202      currentWaiter.unpark();
1203    }
1204  }
1205
1206  /**
1207   * Clears the {@link #listeners} list and prepends its contents to {@code onto}, least recently
1208   * added first.
1209   */
1210  private @Nullable Listener clearListeners(@Nullable Listener onto) {
1211    // We need to
1212    // 1. atomically swap the listeners with TOMBSTONE, this is because addListener uses that
1213    //    to synchronize with us
1214    // 2. reverse the linked list, because despite our rather clear contract, people depend on us
1215    //    executing listeners in the order they were added
1216    // 3. push all the items onto 'onto' and return the new head of the stack
1217    Listener head = ATOMIC_HELPER.gasListeners(this, Listener.TOMBSTONE);
1218    Listener reversedList = onto;
1219    while (head != null) {
1220      Listener tmp = head;
1221      head = head.next;
1222      tmp.next = reversedList;
1223      reversedList = tmp;
1224    }
1225    return reversedList;
1226  }
1227
1228  // TODO(user): move parts into a default method on ListenableFuture?
1229  @Override
1230  public String toString() {
1231    // TODO(cpovirk): Presize to something plausible?
1232    StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
1233    if (getClass().getName().startsWith("com.google.common.util.concurrent.")) {
1234      builder.append(getClass().getSimpleName());
1235    } else {
1236      builder.append(getClass().getName());
1237    }
1238    builder.append('@').append(toHexString(identityHashCode(this))).append("[status=");
1239    if (isCancelled()) {
1240      builder.append("CANCELLED");
1241    } else if (isDone()) {
1242      addDoneString(builder);
1243    } else {
1244      addPendingString(builder); // delegates to addDoneString if future completes midway
1245    }
1246    return builder.append("]").toString();
1247  }
1248
1249  /**
1250   * Provide a human-readable explanation of why this future has not yet completed.
1251   *
1252   * @return null if an explanation cannot be provided (e.g. because the future is done).
1253   * @since 23.0
1254   */
1255  protected @Nullable String pendingToString() {
1256    // TODO(diamondm) consider moving this into addPendingString so it's always in the output
1257    if (this instanceof ScheduledFuture) {
1258      return "remaining delay=[" + ((ScheduledFuture) this).getDelay(MILLISECONDS) + " ms]";
1259    }
1260    return null;
1261  }
1262
1263  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1264  private void addPendingString(StringBuilder builder) {
1265    // Capture current builder length so it can be truncated if this future ends up completing while
1266    // the toString is being calculated
1267    int truncateLength = builder.length();
1268
1269    builder.append("PENDING");
1270
1271    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
1272    if (localValue instanceof SetFuture) {
1273      builder.append(", setFuture=[");
1274      appendUserObject(builder, ((SetFuture) localValue).future);
1275      builder.append("]");
1276    } else {
1277      String pendingDescription;
1278      try {
1279        pendingDescription = Strings.emptyToNull(pendingToString());
1280      } catch (Exception | StackOverflowError e) {
1281        // Any Exception is either a RuntimeException or sneaky checked exception.
1282        //
1283        // Don't call getMessage or toString() on the exception, in case the exception thrown by the
1284        // subclass is implemented with bugs similar to the subclass.
1285        pendingDescription = "Exception thrown from implementation: " + e.getClass();
1286      }
1287      if (pendingDescription != null) {
1288        builder.append(", info=[").append(pendingDescription).append("]");
1289      }
1290    }
1291
1292    // The future may complete while calculating the toString, so we check once more to see if the
1293    // future is done
1294    if (isDone()) {
1295      // Truncate anything that was appended before realizing this future is done
1296      builder.delete(truncateLength, builder.length());
1297      addDoneString(builder);
1298    }
1299  }
1300
1301  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1302  private void addDoneString(StringBuilder builder) {
1303    try {
1304      V value = getUninterruptibly(this);
1305      builder.append("SUCCESS, result=[");
1306      appendResultObject(builder, value);
1307      builder.append("]");
1308    } catch (ExecutionException e) {
1309      builder.append("FAILURE, cause=[").append(e.getCause()).append("]");
1310    } catch (CancellationException e) {
1311      builder.append("CANCELLED"); // shouldn't be reachable
1312    } catch (Exception e) { // sneaky checked exception
1313      builder.append("UNKNOWN, cause=[").append(e.getClass()).append(" thrown from get()]");
1314    }
1315  }
1316
1317  /**
1318   * Any object can be the result of a Future, and not every object has a reasonable toString()
1319   * implementation. Using a reconstruction of the default Object.toString() prevents OOMs and stack
1320   * overflows, and helps avoid sensitive data inadvertently ending up in exception messages.
1321   */
1322  private void appendResultObject(StringBuilder builder, @Nullable Object o) {
1323    if (o == null) {
1324      builder.append("null");
1325    } else if (o == this) {
1326      builder.append("this future");
1327    } else {
1328      builder
1329          .append(o.getClass().getName())
1330          .append("@")
1331          .append(Integer.toHexString(System.identityHashCode(o)));
1332    }
1333  }
1334
1335  /** Helper for printing user supplied objects into our toString method. */
1336  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1337  private void appendUserObject(StringBuilder builder, @Nullable Object o) {
1338    // This is some basic recursion detection for when people create cycles via set/setFuture or
1339    // when deep chains of futures exist resulting in a StackOverflowException. We could detect
1340    // arbitrary cycles using a thread local but this should be a good enough solution (it is also
1341    // what jdk collections do in these cases)
1342    try {
1343      if (o == this) {
1344        builder.append("this future");
1345      } else {
1346        builder.append(o);
1347      }
1348    } catch (Exception | StackOverflowError e) {
1349      // Any Exception is either a RuntimeException or sneaky checked exception.
1350      //
1351      // Don't call getMessage or toString() on the exception, in case the exception thrown by the
1352      // user object is implemented with bugs similar to the user object.
1353      builder.append("Exception thrown from implementation: ").append(e.getClass());
1354    }
1355  }
1356
1357  /**
1358   * Submits the given runnable to the given {@link Executor} catching and logging all {@linkplain
1359   * RuntimeException runtime exceptions} thrown by the executor.
1360   */
1361  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1362  private static void executeListener(Runnable runnable, Executor executor) {
1363    try {
1364      executor.execute(runnable);
1365    } catch (Exception e) { // sneaky checked exception
1366      // Log it and keep going -- bad runnable and/or executor. Don't punish the other runnables if
1367      // we're given a bad one. We only catch Exception because we want Errors to propagate up.
1368      log.get()
1369          .log(
1370              Level.SEVERE,
1371              "RuntimeException while executing runnable "
1372                  + runnable
1373                  + " with executor "
1374                  + executor,
1375              e);
1376    }
1377  }
1378
1379  private abstract static class AtomicHelper {
1380    /** Non-volatile write of the thread to the {@link Waiter#thread} field. */
1381    abstract void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue);
1382
1383    /** Non-volatile write of the waiter to the {@link Waiter#next} field. */
1384    abstract void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue);
1385
1386    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#waiters} field. */
1387    abstract boolean casWaiters(
1388        AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update);
1389
1390    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#listeners} field. */
1391    abstract boolean casListeners(
1392        AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update);
1393
1394    /** Performs a GAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#waiters} field. */
1395    abstract Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update);
1396
1397    /** Performs a GAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#listeners} field. */
1398    abstract Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update);
1399
1400    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#value} field. */
1401    abstract boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update);
1402  }
1403
1404  /** {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@link VarHandle}. */
1405  @J2ObjCIncompatible
1406  // We use this class only after confirming that VarHandle is available at runtime.
1407  @SuppressWarnings("Java8ApiChecker")
1408  @IgnoreJRERequirement
1409  private static final class VarHandleAtomicHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1410    static final VarHandle waiterThreadUpdater;
1411    static final VarHandle waiterNextUpdater;
1412    static final VarHandle waitersUpdater;
1413    static final VarHandle listenersUpdater;
1414    static final VarHandle valueUpdater;
1415
1416    static {
1417      MethodHandles.Lookup lookup = methodHandlesLookupFromWithinAbstractFuture();
1418      try {
1419        waiterThreadUpdater = lookup.findVarHandle(Waiter.class, "thread", Thread.class);
1420        waiterNextUpdater = lookup.findVarHandle(Waiter.class, "next", Waiter.class);
1421        waitersUpdater = lookup.findVarHandle(AbstractFuture.class, "waiters", Waiter.class);
1422        listenersUpdater = lookup.findVarHandle(AbstractFuture.class, "listeners", Listener.class);
1423        valueUpdater = lookup.findVarHandle(AbstractFuture.class, "value", Object.class);
1424      } catch (ReflectiveOperationException e) {
1425        // Those fields exist.
1426        throw newLinkageError(e);
1427      }
1428    }
1429
1430    @Override
1431    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1432      waiterThreadUpdater.setRelease(waiter, newValue);
1433    }
1434
1435    @Override
1436    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1437      waiterNextUpdater.setRelease(waiter, newValue);
1438    }
1439
1440    @Override
1441    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1442      return waitersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1443    }
1444
1445    @Override
1446    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1447      return listenersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1448    }
1449
1450    @Override
1451    Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1452      return (Listener) listenersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1453    }
1454
1455    @Override
1456    Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1457      return (Waiter) waitersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1458    }
1459
1460    @Override
1461    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1462      return valueUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1463    }
1464
1465    private static LinkageError newLinkageError(Throwable cause) {
1466      return new LinkageError(cause.toString(), cause);
1467    }
1468  }
1469
1470  /**
1471   * {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@link sun.misc.Unsafe}.
1472   *
1473   * <p>Static initialization of this class will fail if the {@link sun.misc.Unsafe} object cannot
1474   * be accessed.
1475   */
1476  @SuppressWarnings({"SunApi", "removal"}) // b/345822163
1477  private static final class UnsafeAtomicHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1478    static final Unsafe UNSAFE;
1479    static final long LISTENERS_OFFSET;
1480    static final long WAITERS_OFFSET;
1481    static final long VALUE_OFFSET;
1482    static final long WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET;
1483    static final long WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET;
1484
1485    static {
1486      Unsafe unsafe = null;
1487      try {
1488        unsafe = Unsafe.getUnsafe();
1489      } catch (SecurityException tryReflectionInstead) {
1490        try {
1491          unsafe =
1492              AccessController.doPrivileged(
1493                  new PrivilegedExceptionAction<Unsafe>() {
1494                    @Override
1495                    public Unsafe run() throws Exception {
1496                      Class<Unsafe> k = Unsafe.class;
1497                      for (Field f : k.getDeclaredFields()) {
1498                        f.setAccessible(true);
1499                        Object x = f.get(null);
1500                        if (k.isInstance(x)) {
1501                          return k.cast(x);
1502                        }
1503                      }
1504                      throw new NoSuchFieldError("the Unsafe");
1505                    }
1506                  });
1507        } catch (PrivilegedActionException e) {
1508          throw new RuntimeException("Could not initialize intrinsics", e.getCause());
1509        }
1510      }
1511      try {
1512        Class<?> abstractFuture = AbstractFuture.class;
1513        WAITERS_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("waiters"));
1514        LISTENERS_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("listeners"));
1515        VALUE_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("value"));
1516        WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(Waiter.class.getDeclaredField("thread"));
1517        WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(Waiter.class.getDeclaredField("next"));
1518        UNSAFE = unsafe;
1519      } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) {
1520        throw new RuntimeException(e);
1521      }
1522    }
1523
1524    @Override
1525    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1526      UNSAFE.putObject(waiter, WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET, newValue);
1527    }
1528
1529    @Override
1530    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1531      UNSAFE.putObject(waiter, WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET, newValue);
1532    }
1533
1534    @Override
1535    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1536      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, WAITERS_OFFSET, expect, update);
1537    }
1538
1539    @Override
1540    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1541      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, LISTENERS_OFFSET, expect, update);
1542    }
1543
1544    @Override
1545    Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1546      return (Listener) UNSAFE.getAndSetObject(future, LISTENERS_OFFSET, update);
1547    }
1548
1549    @Override
1550    Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1551      return (Waiter) UNSAFE.getAndSetObject(future, WAITERS_OFFSET, update);
1552    }
1553
1554    @Override
1555    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1556      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, VALUE_OFFSET, expect, update);
1557    }
1558  }
1559
1560  /** {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@link AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater}. */
1561  private static final class AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1562    final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, Thread> waiterThreadUpdater;
1563    final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, Waiter> waiterNextUpdater;
1564    final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Waiter> waitersUpdater;
1565    final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Listener> listenersUpdater;
1566    final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Object> valueUpdater;
1567
1568    AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper(
1569        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, Thread> waiterThreadUpdater,
1570        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, Waiter> waiterNextUpdater,
1571        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Waiter> waitersUpdater,
1572        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Listener> listenersUpdater,
1573        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, Object> valueUpdater) {
1574      this.waiterThreadUpdater = waiterThreadUpdater;
1575      this.waiterNextUpdater = waiterNextUpdater;
1576      this.waitersUpdater = waitersUpdater;
1577      this.listenersUpdater = listenersUpdater;
1578      this.valueUpdater = valueUpdater;
1579    }
1580
1581    @Override
1582    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1583      waiterThreadUpdater.lazySet(waiter, newValue);
1584    }
1585
1586    @Override
1587    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1588      waiterNextUpdater.lazySet(waiter, newValue);
1589    }
1590
1591    @Override
1592    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1593      return waitersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1594    }
1595
1596    @Override
1597    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1598      return listenersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1599    }
1600
1601    @Override
1602    Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1603      return listenersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1604    }
1605
1606    @Override
1607    Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1608      return waitersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1609    }
1610
1611    @Override
1612    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1613      return valueUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1614    }
1615  }
1616
1617  /**
1618   * {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@code synchronized} and volatile writes.
1619   *
1620   * <p>This is an implementation of last resort for when certain basic VM features are broken (like
1621   * AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater).
1622   */
1623  private static final class SynchronizedHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1624    @Override
1625    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1626      waiter.thread = newValue;
1627    }
1628
1629    @Override
1630    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1631      waiter.next = newValue;
1632    }
1633
1634    @Override
1635    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1636      synchronized (future) {
1637        if (future.waiters == expect) {
1638          future.waiters = update;
1639          return true;
1640        }
1641        return false;
1642      }
1643    }
1644
1645    @Override
1646    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1647      synchronized (future) {
1648        if (future.listeners == expect) {
1649          future.listeners = update;
1650          return true;
1651        }
1652        return false;
1653      }
1654    }
1655
1656    @Override
1657    Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1658      synchronized (future) {
1659        Listener old = future.listeners;
1660        if (old != update) {
1661          future.listeners = update;
1662        }
1663        return old;
1664      }
1665    }
1666
1667    @Override
1668    Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1669      synchronized (future) {
1670        Waiter old = future.waiters;
1671        if (old != update) {
1672          future.waiters = update;
1673        }
1674        return old;
1675      }
1676    }
1677
1678    @Override
1679    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1680      synchronized (future) {
1681        if (future.value == expect) {
1682          future.value = update;
1683          return true;
1684        }
1685        return false;
1686      }
1687    }
1688  }
1689
1690  private static CancellationException cancellationExceptionWithCause(
1691      String message, @Nullable Throwable cause) {
1692    CancellationException exception = new CancellationException(message);
1693    exception.initCause(cause);
1694    return exception;
1695  }
1696}
